Not really a bad game (it's based on [i]Half-Life[/i] afterall) but I would only really recommend playing this if you're playing through the entire franchise. 

It doesn't really add anything new to the story (although the character of Barney makes a return in the sequel) and it's also even shorter than [i]Opposing Force[/i] which is easily the superior expansion pack. This has a real "been-there-done-that" kind of feeling which I realise was intentional (the point of these expansions is to see the story from other perspectives) but this doesn't add anything interesting level design or weapons (having fewer weapons than both the original and [i]Opposing Force[/i]).

However, it is short like I previously stated so you might as well play through it once.

Worth playing if you are a fan of the half life series.

HALF-LIFE: BLUE SHIFT<

The third installment in the half-life series is once again the progeny of valve teaming with gearbox. It brought fewer new elements into the game than the previous two and wasn't well acclaimed by fans. The game upon release on steam suffers from bugs caused by the engine changing and various other things. The game was also originally supposed to be an exclusive for the doomed Sega Dreamcast. The plot takes place during the events of half-life and Instead of playing as gordon freeman, you play as the ordinary watchman Barney Calhoun(the one you see banging on the door in the beginning of half-life). The story also features some new faces not yet seen in the series.

PROS:
-The story is very well paced and put together very nicely. You play as Barney Calhoun during the cascade and cover up operation in black mesa. Not spoiling the rest in case you haven't picked up a copy in the 20 years its existed.
-The environment is very immersive as it is a long seamless road to the end of the game with, as the definition of seamless implies, zero cutscenes or immersion breaking interruptions.
-The gunplay involves the same weapons from half-life with no new additions. The arsenal available is pleasently loud, very powerful feeling, and quite fun to use when eliminating the enemy.
-The ending is great for what it is
-Has an HD reskin to give a fresh coat of paint.

CONS: (Not even half-life is safe from sin, sorry) Please note that i am extremely aware that this game is an oldy.
-Controls feel floaty and thats not very great to say when this game is a puzzle platformer.
-Same issues as the original, guns feel not very effective at some times and very effective at others. No idea whats going on here but it hasn't deterred me from playing.
-Unlike the other half-life games before this one, this installment is the buggiest out of the bunch. Plentiful missed triggers and some doors not opening like they should all throughout the entirety of the game. Buy at ones own risk.

This game isn't a must have unlike the original but usually it comes bundled with it so give it a play(used to come free). I picked the entire series up in a frantic buy in a summer sale and it was worth it. if anything it's textures for gmod if you don't have much interest in it. With the bugs still not being fixed to this very day we have the second lowest score out of all half-life games that i'll be giving out.

6 blue vests out of 10

The game is very much available elsewhere but hasn't had an offical release on steam. Only thing i can do is go overtime on this one and plant my review here. DOUBLE REVIEW.

[h1]"Otra perspectiva"[/h1]

Half life 1: Blue Shift, es (canonicamente) la segunda expnasión para Half life 1, lanzada por Valve en el 2001.

Basicamente se nos presenta la misma historia del Half-Life original, pero de una perspectiva completamente diferente, siendo esta vez "Barney Calhoun" un guardia de seguridad común en las instalaciones de "Black Mesa", quien después de la cascada de resonancias provocado por Gordon Freeman y su equipo, intenta liberar a un grupo de cientificos supervivientes para salir con vida de las instalaciones.

Presenta una banda sonora muy ausente, mismos controles de movimiento, mismas armas (y menos que en el juego original) y tiene una duración aproximada de 1 hora y media.

Lo único destacable es la trama, que nos otorga una distintas visión del desastre ocurrido de la cascada de resonancias producidas en Black Mesa, logrando ver un lado mucho más "humano" y preocupado por el bienestar de cientificos y otros guardias de seguridad que logramos ver durante el juego.

Un buen juego para pasar una tarde.

[b]+[/b] One can expect any [i]Half-Life[/i] game to be immersive, destructive, interactive, and fast-paced, as well as have puzzles that are complex or physically correct, in which case [i]Blue Shift[/i] is one of those games.
[b]+[/b] Story is well-developed and practical, told from the viewpoint of a Black Mesa security guard named Barney Calhoun, and like [i]Opposing Force[/i], the dialogue is smooth thanks to the development of the characters (which are the primary source of this game's storytelling), notably for Dr. Rosenburg. Also like [i]Opposing Force[/i], most of the scientists and security guards can still talk idiotically, but that is no big deal, as not only does it not affect the quality of the story, but it also adds humor to the atmosphere of the gameplay.
[b]=[/b] The introduction of the high-definition pack does add graphical improvements to the game, later seen via update in [i]Half-Life[/i] and [i]Opposing Force[/i]. Unfortunately, it also comes with the side effect that as a 2001 standalone expansion pack to the 1998 game, the game engine appears to be outdated or largely unchanged when compared to other 2001 games.
[b]-[/b] Far too derivative of the original. Although the game features a different protagonist set in the same time as the original [i]Half-Life[/i] with the story being about his own experience, the formula is largely the same as in the original, and unlike the earlier expansion pack, [i]Opposing Force[/i], this game has mostly textures and models from the original, with a few either being designed for this game or, in the case of even fewer textures and models, from the previous expansion pack.
[b]-[/b] With about 4 hours of campaign and no multiplayer, the game is super short, even being a little shorter than [i]Opposing Force[/i].

[b]Conclusion:[/b] There may not be anything totally new in [i]Half-Life: Blue Shift[/i], but its series of more levels, and the important fundamentals of what makes a game [i]Half-Life[/i], should keep its fans, as well as casuals, occupied with 4 hours of campaign for a game that retains its style.

[b]SCORE: 65%[/b]

Half-Life: Blue Shift to drugi samodzielny dodatek do Half-Life, za które odpowiedzialne jest Gearbox Software, a wydane przez Valve w 2001 roku. Gra poza wprowadzeniem teksturek HD, innymi lokacjami oraz ukazaniem wydarzeń z innej perspektywy gra niczego nowego nie wnosi, walczymy z tymi samymi przeciwnikami co w zwykłym Half-Life, mamy mniej broni oraz jest bardzo krótka. What enabled the resonance cascade? Surely, Freeman might have put the final nail in the coffin, but what more factors could have affected the outcome? A broken supercomputer, a malevolent Russian infiltrator; or perhaps an oversleeping scientist. The possibilities are torrential, and in retrospect anything seems conceivable ... perhaps the catastrophe could have been avoided?

[b]Meet Barney Calhoun[/b], a Black Mesa security guard. His job is simple; main objective: to protect facility equipment and research personnel. He may have Level 3 security clearance into the top-secret Sector B, but don't be deceived - Calhoun is an ordinary guy. But he is about to experience something extraordinary.
  The 16th of May started out just like any other day: the halls of Black Mesa are still somewhat empty,  tired staff grumbles their discontent over yet another early morning, the complex has not yet sprung to life. Calhoun is savoring the silence of the break of day; but suddenly something breaks the silence. Gunshots from down the corridor echoes throughout the vacant rooms. Down the hallway the shooting range has fallen victims to its first wielders, confirming the outset of a new day. A few guards steps through the entrance and greets Calhoun, as if just to confirm it further. 
  For an outsider the halls could be hard to navigate, but for the employees it's perfunctory. A left turn; another left; straight forward and to the right: Barney enters the locker-room. It's mandatory to wear your bulletproof vest at all times, and today is no exception. His locker creaks uninvitingly - as if auguring the imminent event - and it sends his 9mm pistol (it's standard-issue among the wardens) toppling to the ground with a resounding clunk. Some turned their heads, others couldn't be bothered. He picked it up and shifted its weight in his palm. The cold metal sent chills down his spine. Chills, in the most delightful meaning of the word. Barney Calhoun is ready for duty….

[b]Blue Shift[/b] is the second and ultimate expansion pack for Half Life, offering a final viewpoint on the legendary disaster. It contains the same elements you might expect from a Half-Life title: aliens, guns and puzzle-solving - heuristics can be the only way forward. But unlike its precursor, this standalone game do not feature any new substance. Gameplay remain identical to that of the original which hankering fans discerned as trite. In a lamentable juxtaposition of the series previous releases, Blue Shift received a lukewarm reception. Critics claimed it was somewhat abbreviated and largely regarded it as “more of the same”. Although; when it comes to Half-Life, more of the same doesn't sound that bad.

This is a short expansion pack to Half-Life, shorter than Opposing Force. Not only in story length, but in gameplay elements as well; it features less weapons, the same enemies of HL and no new game mechanics. However it expands further in the story of Black Mesa and the events that led to HL catastrophe, all presented from yet another perspective: Barney Calhoun, a security guard. 

In short, this game is an expansion in all the extent of the word, rather than a side story (as Opposing Force is).

Blue Shift is a game for the Half-Life completionist; or perhaps more accurately, people who buy a Half-Life bundle.  If you've finished HL1 and Opposing Force and feel like another couple of hours of that, only not quite as good, Blue Shift might be able to satisfy.

The main problem is that this is short and has very little new content over HL1.  No new weapons, no new enemies, not even all of the ones that showed up in the main game.  It also lacks the polish in its set pieces that the original has, and has rather more back-tracking than other games in this universe.  That said, the gameplay is still enjoyable; it's still Half-Life, even if the weakest incarnation.

Gameplay aside, there's little other reason to play this.  The story of one security guard's escape is rather low-key and underwhelming.  Yes, the player character shares the name of the NPC from HL2.   But as a silent protagonist, he has no personality and might as well be anyone.  There is some world-building as we see more of Black Mesa, including its history with teleportation experiments, and its done fairly competently.  But it's not enough by itself to play this.

В Blue Shift нас запускают в шкуру Барни Калхуна – одного из тех несчастных охранников «Черной Мезы», что завернуты в синие костюмчики. Кроме небольшой смены «угла зрения» (читай: пачки карт для новой кампании) никаких нововведений означенная смена не предусматривает. Сама кампания никудышная, карты оформлены бедно и абсолютно безыдейно. Действо сопровождается музыкой, выдернутой из предыдущего адд-она, Opposing Force, причем, что самое замечательное, оттуда были позаимствованы самые отвратительные треки. Одно хорошо – «Синяя смена» чрезвычайно короткая; прохождение занимает часа 3 от силы.

Единственным интересным моментом Blue Shift в свое время был вот какой: на диске вместе с игрой поставлялся бонус – пакет новых, высокодетализированных моделек оружия и вражин. Этот пакет можно было напялить также и на оригинальный Half-Life, и на Opposing Force (сейчас во всех трех играх в «Стиме» уже по умолчанию есть специальный переключатель в настройках). Правда, лично я «отреставрированные» модели не перевариваю: они лучше детализированы, все так, однако часть новых экземпляров выглядит безвкусно. 

Подведем итоги. У Blue Shift есть свои достоинства. Кампания короткая, как уже упоминалось выше – это первый несомненный плюс. А кроме того, бывают шутеры и хуже; в конце концов, это же Half-Life. Только лишь жалко скроенный.

It's an interesting design. The game takes place in parallel with the story of Half Life. I won't Spoil the details the story, but it's a solid entry and I would say, if you liked the original Half Life, you'll love blue Shift. 

BUT, this isn't a perfect game, far from it, and gameplay-wise you'll see some rough edges. For example, in the beginning the amount of enemies, that you face is reasonable and most of their attacks can be avoided. About halfway through the game, you are faced with a bunch of hitscanning bullet sponges that are spam spawning across the map. 

I don't think that it's the game developers' fault, but rather the botched final update of the base: Half-Life, it shipped with. 

If you've played the original Half-Life, you'll notice the differences: some weapon models like the mp5 and the Glock were replaced by M4 (which makes NO SENSE), and the Beretta. There were also some "minor" balancing tweaks like decreased headshot damage to Hecu soldiers, which make this game a chore to play through. It's not terrible, but not particularly great either... 

Still this is an excellent piece of nostalgia, with excellent Linux support.
